Subjects may include persons, objects, or events, and may be recognized through computer vision techniques as well as using contextual data. The imaging device may receive social network data from one or more social network servers, which may be used to determine the relevant social network groups. The imaging device may also exclude subjects from the cropped sub-images based on one or more content policies. Other embodiments are described and claimed.

title: Assisted update of knowledge base for problem solving
abstract: A system and method for proposing candidate solutions for updating a knowledge base are disclosed. In the method, knowledge base solutions in a natural language are each processed to generate a first action sequence of atomic steps, each including a verb and an object including a noun which is in a syntactic dependency with the respective verb. A recorded solution, expressed in a natural language, is received which includes actions performed on a device in the device class. The recorded solution is processed to generate a second action sequence of atomic steps, as for the first action sequence. The second action sequence is compared with the first action sequences to determine whether the recorded solution corresponds to one of the knowledge base solutions. Based on the comparison, provision is made for proposing an update to the knowledge base, based on the recorded solution.

title: Detection of side channel attacks between virtual machines
abstract: Technologies are directed to a detector to identify a side channel attack between virtual machines. According to some examples, an inter-processor interrupt (IPI) rate of a first virtual machine (VM), a time stamp counter (TSC) rate of a second VM, and a cache miss ratio (CMR) of a third VM may be monitored. A side channel attack may then be detected based on the IPI rate, the TSC rate, and the CMR.

title: Osteoporosis diagnostic support apparatus
abstract: Provided is an apparatus for measuring the thickness, roughness, and morphology index of the mandibular cortical bone using a dental panorama image to assist in the diagnosis of osteoporosis, wherein the thickness, roughness, and morphological index of the cortical bone is measured more accurately and the diagnosis of osteoporosis can be supported more accurately. An osteoporosis diagnostic support apparatus, wherein the apparatus has a contour extraction unit adapted to extract a mandibular contour from an image of a mandibular cortical bone photographed by a photographic apparatus adapted to photograph the mandibular cortical bone and surroundings thereof, a line segment extraction unit adapted to extract line segments from the image of the mandibular cortical bone photographed by the photographic apparatus; and a cortical bone thickness calculation unit adapted to calculate a thickness of the cortical bone based on the extracted mandibular contour and line segments.

title: Target marking for secure logo validation process
abstract: The instant application describes a method for acquiring via a vehicle wheel alignment system an image of a target including a validation logo, the validation logo being used for recognition by the vehicle wheel alignment system and determination of authenticity of the validation logo by the vehicle wheel alignment system; identifying the validation logo within the image of the target; comparing the identified validation logo with a reference validation logo; computing a similarity metric based on a result of a comparison between the identified validation logo and the reference validation logo; and based on the computed similarity metric, enabling or disabling the vehicle wheel alignment system.

title: Determining additional features for a task entry based on a user habit
abstract: Methods and apparatus related to determining additional features for a user task entry of a user based on a user habit of the user. For example, one or more aspects of a user task entry of a user may be compared to one or more aspects of a user habit of the user to determine a correlation measure between the task entry and the user habit. If the correlation measure satisfies a threshold, one or more additional features of the user task entry may be determined based on the user habit. For example, the user habit may include one or more trigger indicators that indicate an actual entry or anticipated entry of the user into the user habit, and one or more of the trigger indicators may be utilized to determine task trigger indicators for the user task entry.

title: Basecaller for DNA sequencing using machine learning
abstract: Methods, systems, and apparatuses are provided for creating and using a machine-leaning model to call a base at a position of a nucleic acid based on intensity values measured during a production sequencing run. The model can be trained using training data from training sequencing runs performed earlier. The model is trained using intensity values and assumed sequences that are determined as the correct output. The training data can be filtered to improve accuracy. The training data can be selected in a specific manner to be representative of the type of organism to be sequenced. The model can be trained to use intensity signals from multiple cycles and from neighboring nucleic acids to improve accuracy in the base calls.

title: Tap to initiate a next action for user requests
abstract: Embodiments may relate to intuitive user-interface features for a head-mountable device (HMD), in the context of a hybrid human and computer-automated response system. An illustrative method may involve a head-mountable device (HMD) that comprises a touchpad: (a) sending a speech-segment message to a hybrid response system, wherein the speech-segment message is indicative of a speech segment that is detected in audio data captured at the HMD, and wherein the speech-segment is associated with a first user-account with the hybrid response system, (b) receiving a response message that includes a response to the speech-segment message and an indication of a next action corresponding to the response to the speech-segment message, (c) displaying a screen interface that includes an indication of the response, and (d) while displaying the response, detecting a singular touch gesture and responsively initiating the at least one next action.

title: Use of an infant formula containing sweet whey to promote postnatal neural development of the infant's digestive tract and the establishment of the intestinal functions it controls
abstract: DESCRIPTION Use of an infant formula containing sweet whey to promote postnatal neural development of the infant's digestive tract and the establishment of the intestinal functions it controls field of invention The present invention relates, in general, to the field of neuronal health, protection and development. The invention specifically relates to the administration of sweet whey protein to promote enteric neuronal development in infants, especially preterm, low, very low, and extremely low birth weight infants. Background of the invention The nervous system is a very complex network, made up of neurons and glia. It is present in all mammalian species and is composed of the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) and the peripheral nervous system (somatic, autonomic, and enteric nervous systems). The central nervous system directs cognitive functions (memory, attention, perception, action, etc.). Together with the peripheral nervous system, it has a fundamental role in behavior control. The somatic nervous system is responsible for the coordination of bodily movements (with conscious control). The autonomic nervous system maintains homeostasis in bodily activities without conscious control (heart rate, etc.). Finally, and as part of the last system, the enteric nervous system directly controls the functions of the digestive tract. These include the immune and barrier function, motility, absorption, digestion and exocrine/endocrine secretions of the digestive tract, which contribute to the protection of the intestine against any type of injury and to the well-being of the digestive system [Neunlist, M et al. (2008); Neuroglial crosstalk in inflammatory bowel disease, J Intern. Med, 263: 577-583], [Burns, A.J. et al. (2009); Development of the enteric nervous system and its role in intestinal motility during fetal and early postnatal stages, Semin. Pediatric Surg., 18: 196-205], [Tapper E.J. (1983); Local modulation of intestinal ion transport by enteric neurons, Am J Physiol., 244: G457-68]. The nervous system develops during gestation and is then redefined into a mature and functional network during the postnatal (after birth) period. Due to the critical role of the enteric nervous system in digestive function, immaturity or delayed maturation of the nervous system will lead to a delay in the establishment and proper functioning of major digestive functions. In particular, it will contribute to: • immaturity of digestive motility [Burns, A.J. et al. (2009); Development of the enteric nervous system and its role in intestinal motility during fetal and early postnatal stages, Semin. Pediatric Surg., 18: 196-205], which will result in slower intestinal transit with harder stools that will lead to intestinal discomfort and, in most cases, extreme constipation, with a greater predisposition of the baby to enteral feeding intolerance, to a need for total parenteral nutrition and, in more severe cases, necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) (Grave GD, Nelson SA, Walker WA, Moss RL, Dvorak B, Hamilton FA, Higgins R, Raju TN. New therapies and preventive approaches for necrotizing enterocolitis: report of a research planning workshop Pediatr Res. J Matern Fetal Neonatal Med. 2011 Oct;24 Sup. 1:64-6 • reduce intestinal digestive/absorptive capacity [Tapper, E.J. (1983); Local modulation of intestinal ion transport by enteric neurons, Am J Physiol., 244: G457-68]; Josef Neu and Liyan Zhang, Feeding intolerance in very low birth weight infants: What is it and what can we do about it? Pediatric Act 2005; 94(sup. 449): 93-99] • immaturity of intestinal barrier function [Neunlist, M. et al. (2008); Neuroglial crosstalk in inflammatory bowel disease, J Intern. Med, 263: 577-583, Burns, A.J. et al. (2009)], which increases the risk of infections, enteral feeding intolerance and necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) [Athalye-Jape G, More K, Patole S Progress in the field of necrotizing enterocolitis--year 2012.. J Matern Fetal Neonatal Med . May 2013; 26(7): 625-32; Indrio F, Riezzo G, Cavallo L, Di Mauro A, Francavilla R. Physiological basis of food intolerance in VLBW. J Matern Fetal Neonatal Med Oct 2011; 24 Sup. 1: 64-6] An immature or affected enteric nervous system can be seen in babies such as: - Premature, low (<2500 g), very low (<1500 g) and extremely low (<1000 g) birth weight babies; New J. Digestive development and meeting the nutritional needs of premature infants Am J Clin Nutr 2007; 85(2): 629S-634S. - Premature or full-term babies with intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) produced after any adverse event during pregnancy (mother who smokes, mother with drug treatment, low  quality of the placenta, incorrect placement of the placenta, malnutrition of the mother and fetus, excessive stress/anxiety of the mother, etc.); [Shanklin DR and Cooke RJ (1993); Effects of intrauterine growth on intestinal length in the human fetus, Biol Neonate, 64:76-81], [Neu, J. (2007); Digestive development and meeting the nutritional needs of premature infants, Am. J. Clin. Nutr., 85(2): 629S-634S], [Brandaoa, MCS et al., (2003); Effects of pre- and postnatal protein energy deprivation on the myenteric plexus of the small intestine: a morphometric study in weanling rats, Nutr. Res., 23: 215-223]. - Any neonate and young child showing growth retardation of the nervous system after, for example, hypoxemia-ischemia at birth or any other adverse event [Taylor, C.T. and Colgan S.P. (2007); Hypoxia and digestive disease, J. Mol. Med. (Berl.), 85:1295-300], [Barrett R.D. et al. (2007); Destruction and reconstruction: hypoxia and the developing brain, Birth Defects Res C Embryo Today, 81: 163-76]. - Any neonate and young child showing digestive disturbances (digestive disorders, related motility disorders, GI reflux, slow GI tract, intolerance to oral feeding), Hirschsprung's disease and inflammation involving the GI tract (such as necrotizing enterocolitis) and obstruction-related pathologies [Burns A.J. et al. (2009); Development of the enteric nervous system and its role in intestinal motility during fetal and early postnatal stages, Semin. Pediatr Surg., 18(4): 196-205]. It is known that, in humans, the neural crest cells, from which the enteric nervous system derives, develop in the fetus when it is in utero, very early after conception (from 7.5 weeks of development) [Burns, A. J. & Thapar, N. (2006); Advances in ontogeny of the enteric nervous system, Neurogastroenterol. Motil., 18, 876-887]. The enteric nervous system has been observed to undergo major changes after birth up to six years, continuing with more minor changes up to ten years [Wester, T. et al. (1999); Notable postnatal alterations in the myenteric plexus of normal human bowel, Gut, 44: 666-674]. Therefore, if the fetus, neonate or infant has had a delay in the growth of the nervous system, it is desirable that this delay be rapidly reversed such that the development of the nervous system "reaches" a normal level. It is desirable that any damage caused to the enteric nervous system be repaired as soon as possible, so that the fetus or growing infant hardly suffers from intestinal disturbances or other pathologies associated with an immature or damaged enteric nervous system. Thus, the healthy development of the enteric nervous system in the fetus, neonate, and growing child helps to control the proper establishment and maintenance of intestinal motility, intestinal barrier function, and thus the absorptive and digestive functions of the intestinal tract. intestine. This prevents inflammatory disease states associated with intestinal disorders and also reduces the risk of infections and allergies (Neunlist et al. 2008) Therefore, postnatal interventions correspond to a promising strategy to ensure the healthy development of the enteric nervous system. There is a need to promote and reinforce the healthy development and/or repair of the enteric nervous system during the early phases of the newborn's life, when the nervous system matures rapidly. Since the nervous system continues to develop during the early years of childhood (up to about ten years of age), during this period of time there is this need for continuous reinforcement. In particular, there is a need to support the healthy development of the enteric nervous system in neonates, infants, and young children, to better prepare them for digestive challenges such as dietary changes, chemicals (eg, medications), or physical injury (abrasion ), infections, inflammatory/immune reactions, etc., as well as to enhance the future maturation of their enteric nervous system during later life. For this purpose or related purposes, compositions comprising lactoferrin, probiotics, soluble fiber and/or LCPUFA (Long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids) have been disclosed, for example, in documents US 2012/0184483; US 2012/0219526; EP 2609813; US 2007/0031537 and US 2013/0280225. There is a need to improve said booster or said related composition, in a way that is well accepted by the population in question, in particular those populations that are more fragile and need it the most. There is a further need not to induce disadvantages, side or negative effects in said population. There is a need to provide such solutions to the populations in question in a simpler and more cost-effective manner. The present invention applies to humans. Summary of the invention The invention is defined by the claims and refers to the use of sweet whey protein (SLP) to promote healthy development and/or repair the enteric nervous system in neonates. The sweet whey protein may be modified sweet whey protein (MLDP), from which the caseinoglycomacropeptide (CGMP) has been removed. PLD can be partially or extensively hydrolyzed. More specifically, the present invention relates to  sweet whey protein for use in the prevention and treatment of at least one disorder associated with an immature or affected enteric nervous system in an infant or young child, wherein the sweet whey protein is administered to the infant or young child as a daily dose of 30 to 80% of total protein intake. The administration of sweet whey protein promotes the normal and healthy development of neurons and glial cells in the intestine. It also ensures healthy neural differentiation in the peripheral nervous system. Therefore, the administration of the PLD according to the invention prevents and treats disorders associated with an immature or affected enteric nervous system. Administration of the PLD according to the invention promotes the healthy development and/or repair of the enteric nervous system in small mammals. The disorder may be intestinal barrier dysfunction, food intolerance, or necrotizing enterocolitis. The disorder may be one that is directly associated with intestinal barrier dysfunction. More generally, the disorder may be dysfunctional digestive motility that may manifest as reduced intestinal transit, intestinal discomfort, hard stools, constipation, and/or digestive reflux. Sweet whey protein can be administered to a premature or full-term baby. Administration can also be to a child, generally up to six years of age, or the equivalent age in an animal. Sweet whey protein can be administered directly to the baby, or to the baby who is already taking his first steps (toddler),in its pure form, or diluted in water or breast milk, in a food supplement, or together with a milk fortifier or any Milk booster used during trophic feeding, in a baby formula, or in a milk drink. Sweet whey protein is administered to the infant or young child as a daily dose of 30 to 80%, preferably 60% w/w, of the total protein intake. The administration period for the infant or young child is generally at least 4 months, preferably 2-12 months, and more preferably at least 18 months and even more preferably until the child is six years old. PLDM can be given to a premature or full-term infant, or to a child or young adult, as a dose of 1.6-3.2 g protein/100 kcal, preferably 1.6-2.2 g protein /100 kcal, and more preferably 1.8-2.1 g protein/100 kcal. In one embodiment, the PLDM is administered to the child as a dose of 1.0 to less than 1.6 g protein/100 kcal. The invention relates to a composition comprising 30-80%, preferably 60% sweet whey protein, for the prevention or treatment of disorders associated with the immature or affected enteric nervous system in a young mammal. Also disclosed is the use of a PLD, and more particularly compositions comprising 30-80% w/w PLD, to promote healthy development and/or repair the enteric nervous system in young mammals. Detailed description Definitions: In this specification, the following terms have the following meanings: "Infants":According to Commission Directive 2006/141/EC of December 22, 2006 on infant formulas and follow-up formulas, article 1.2 (a), the term "infant" means a child under 12 months of age. “Neonate”generally means an infant up to 6 months of age. "Premature baby"generally refers to a baby born before 37 weeks of gestation. “Term baby”generally refers to a baby born after 37 weeks of gestation. "Babywho is already taking his first steps" generally refers to a child from when he begins to walk until he is three years old. "Toddler"generally refers to a child from one to ten years of age (and the equivalent age in animals where the term"small mammal" is used). "Sweet Modified Whey Protein"(PLDM) or"Sweet Modified Whey"(SLDM) means sweet whey protein from which some or all of the caseinoglycomacropeptides (CGMPs) have been removed. In various embodiments of the invention the caseinoglycomacropeptide (CGMP) of the SLDM is reduced by greater than 60%, greater than 75%, greater than 90%, greater than 95% or greater than 99% (w/w) compared to the amount present on average in natural milk whey of the same origin (for example sweet bovine milk whey). "Probiotic"means preparations of microbial cells or components of microbial cells that have a beneficial effect on the health or well-being of the recipient. [Salminen, S. et al. (1999); Probiotics: how should they be defined, Trends Food Sci Technol., 10107-10] The definition of a probiotic is generally accepted and consistent with the WHO definition.The probiotic may comprise a single strain of microorganism, a mixture of several strains, and/or a mixture of several species and genera of bacteria. In the case of mixtures, the term "probiotic" in the singular can nevertheless be used to refer to the probiotic mixture or preparation. For the purposes of the present invention, microorganisms of the genusLactobacillusare considered as probiotics. "Prebiotic"generally refers to a non-digestible food ingredient that beneficially influences the recipient, selectively stimulating the growth and/or activity of microorganisms present in the recipient's intestine, and therefore intended to improve their health. "Allergy"means an allergy that has been detected by a physician and can be treated occasionally or on a more lasting basis. A "food allergy" is an allergy to a nutritional composition. "Infant formula"according to Commission Directives 2006/141/EC of December 22, 2006 and/or 91/321/EEC of May 14, 1991 on infant formulas and follow-on formulas, article 1.2(c) , the expression "infant formula" means food products intended for a particular nutritional use for infants during the first four to six months of life and which by themselves satisfy the nutritional needs of this category of persons. It is to be understood that infants may be exclusively fed infant formula, or that infant formula may be used by the caregiver as a supplement to human milk. This expression is synonymous with the expression "start formula" so generally used. "Continuation formula":according to Commission Directives 2006/141/EC of December 22, 2006 and/or 91/321/EEC of May 14, 1991 on infant formulas and follow-on formulas, article 1.2 (d), the term "follow-on formula" means food products intended for particular nutritional use for infants older than four months and which constitutes the main liquid element in a progressively diversified diet for this category of people. "Growing milk":dairy nutritional composition specially adapted for children between one and three years of age. "Human milk fortifier":nutritional composition for infants or young children, intended to be added to or diluted with human milk. The term"hypoallergenic composition"means a composition that is unlikely to cause allergic reactions. The term"sialylated oligosaccharide"means an oligosaccharide having a sialic acid moiety. The term"fucosylated oligosaccharide"means an oligosaccharide having a fucose residue. All percentages are by weight unless otherwise indicated. As used in this specification, the words "comprising", "comprising" and similar words, are not to be construed in an exclusive or exhaustive sense. In other words, they are intended to mean "including, but not limited to." In this specification, any reference to prior art documents should not be taken as an admission that the prior art is widely known or forms part of the common general knowledge in this field. Dietary proteins provide the essential amino acids necessary for protein synthesis and growth, and the quality of the protein is just as important as its quantity. The present invention provides a sweet whey protein for use by administration to promote healthy development of the mammalian enteric nervous system. Sweet whey can be obtained from cheese making, particularly sweet whey obtained from the coagulation of casein by rennet. The sweet whey protein of the invention comprises 30-100% w/w protein, preferably >80% w/w protein. An example of a PLD that can be used in accordance with the invention is a PLD marketed under the trade name Lacprodan Di9224™. Thus, the PLD may be in the form of a sweet whey protein isolate or a sweet whey protein concentrate. According to one embodiment of the invention, the sweet whey protein is a modified sweet whey fraction, ie it is a sweet whey protein having a reduced level of caseinoglycomacropeptide (CGMP) compared to a classical sweet whey protein. This fraction of sweet whey is called Sweet Modified Whey (MLDM). A classic sweet whey can contain from 4 to 40% CGMP depending on the processing of the milk. The protein fraction in cow's milk is a mixture of various proteins, all with a different amino acid profile. Caseinoglycomacropeptide (CGMP) is derived from the proteolysis of kappa-casein into parakappa-casein, an insoluble fraction that remains in the casein fraction, and CGMP, a soluble fraction that is found in the whey fraction. This CGMp-reduced whey fraction or SLDM provides the advantage of reduced threonine content and increased tryptophan content compared to normal sweet whey and is therefore suitable as a protein source for infants. . This sweet whey fraction can be further treated to remove minerals (cations, anions), lactose or any of these substances. The sweet whey can be concentrated as desired. Suitable sources of sweet whey are commercially available. Removal of the caseinoglycomacropeptide can be accomplished by any suitable process. A suitable process is described in EP0880902. In this process, the pH of the sweet whey is adjusted from 1 to 4.3, if necessary. The sweet whey is then contacted with a weakly anionic resin that is predominantly alkaline until the pH of the sweet whey stabilizes at about 4.5 to 5.5. Then, the sweet whey fraction, from which a significant amount of caseinoglycomacropeptide is removed, is collected. According to one embodiment of the invention, this CGMP-reduced whey protein fraction contains approximately 28% protein, of which CGMP represents 2-3% of total protein, and is therefore designated "PLDM28". SLDM for use according to the invention may, of course, contain a higher percentage of protein than in PLDM28, for example 30 to 99% protein. Similarly, the SLDM for use according to the invention may also contain a higher percentage of CGMP than in PLDM28, eg up to 15, 20, 25 or 35% of total protein. According to another embodiment of the invention, the sweet whey protein is unmodified and comprises a minimum of 50% protein. For example, PLD sold under the trademark Lacprodan Di9224™ from Aria Foods Ingredients, Skanderborgvej 277, 8260 Viby J, Denmark, contains 87% protein. Other examples of commercially available unmodified sweet whey protein for use in accordance with the invention are Lacprodan DI-8790, another sweet whey from Aria, 894 Instantised and MPC 485 available from Fonterra (New Zealand), YV0608, Armor Protéines (France) and BiPro, Davisco Food International inc (US, 11000 West 78th Street, Suite 210, Eden Prairie, MN 55344). Sweet whey protein may be non-hydrolyzed. Alternatively, according to some embodiments of the invention, the sweet whey protein is partially or extensively hydrolyzed to prevent allergic reactions from occurring in babies at risk of allergy and to make the protein easier to digest. The hydrolysis process can be carried out as desired and as known in the art. In general, the whey protein hydrolyzate is prepared by enzymatically hydrolyzing the sweet whey fraction in one or more steps. For example, for an extensively hydrolyzed protein, sweet whey proteins can be subjected to triple hydrolysis using, for example, Alcalase 2.4L (EC 940459), then Neutrase 0.5L (available from Novo Nordisk Ferment AG) and then pancreatin at 55°C. . Alternatively, for a less hydrolyzed protein, sweet whey can be double hydrolyzed using, for example, NOVOZYMES and then pancreatin. If the sweet whey protein used is substantially free of lactose, the protein is found to undergo much less lysine blockage during the hydrolysis process. This allows the degree of lysine blockage to be reduced from about 15% by weight of total lysine to less than about 10% by weight of lysine; for example about 7% by weight of lysine. This greatly improves the nutritional quality of the protein source. The administration of the PLD can be to a premature or full-term baby directly. Administration may also be to a small child, generally up to the age of four years or equivalent age in an animal. Administration of LPD to the young mammal, which can be a human (infant, toddler or toddler) or animal, has a positive effect on the development of its enteric nervous system, which allows the system to mature and develop normally. Thus, administration of the sweet whey protein according to the invention prevents and treats disorders associated with an immature or affected enteric nervous system. These disorders can be, for example, intestinal barrier dysfunction, food intolerance or necrotizing enterocolitis. These latter states increase the risk of infections and allergies, thus leading to food intolerance (hence the need for parenteral nutritional support). More generally, these disorders can be dysfunctional digestive motility that can manifest as slow intestinal transit, intestinal discomfort, hard stools, constipation and/or digestive reflux. The beneficial effect of the invention is especially directed at those young mammals that have had, for example, intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) that may have occurred after any adverse event during pregnancy (for example, a passive or active smoking mother, a mother with pharmacological treatment, low quality of the placenta, incorrect placement of the placenta, malnutrition of the mother and/or fetus, etc.). The present inventors have discovered that PLD and/or PLD-containing compositions of the present invention can be used to promote the development, functionality, survival, plasticity and differentiation of neurons and to protect them against degeneration, as shown by promoting the expression of proteins associated with those biological activities. In infants, PLD and/or PLD-containing compositions of the present invention can be used to protect the enteric nervous system from any type of stress, for example, occurring during the period of neuronal development and - consequently - limit and/or prevent stress-induced neuronal growth retardation and associated intestinal dysfunctions. Therefore, PLD can be administered, in the context of the present invention, when a delay in the development of the enteric nervous system has already been observed or, prophylactically, when such a delay has not yet been observed. The beneficial effect of PLD on the healthy development of the mammalian enteric nervous system is described in more detail in the following paragraphs. PLD dose: Sweet whey protein can be given to infants or young children at a dose of 1.6-3.2 g protein/100 kcal, preferably 1.6-2.2 g protein/100 kcal and even more preferably 1.8-2.1 g of protein/100 kcal. For premature babies there are specific recommendations, published by the ESPGHAN Committee on Nutrition, about the amount of protein they should receive. For premature babies with a birth weight of less than 1 kg, the recommended protein intake is 3.6 to 4.1 g protein/100 kcal. For babies with a birth weight between 1 and 1.8 kg, the recommended intake of protein content is 3.2 to 3.6 g protein/100 kcal [Agostini et al (2010) JPGN 2010 (50), 1, Enteral Nutrient Supply for Preterm Infants]. Therefore, the amount of PLD administered to a premature infant is appropriately tailored based on current recommendations. For example, if according to one embodiment of the invention the PLD has a protein content of 100% and the PLD represents 80% of the total protein that is administered to the premature infant, then a suitable amount of PLD to be administered to the premature infant is 2.8-3.2 g per 100 kcal for babies whose body weight is less than 1 kg and 2.5-2.9 g for babies whose body weight is 1 kg-1.8 kg. The dose of PLD administered is such that the subject's protein intake is within appropriate guidelines (eg, WHO and ESPGHAN Committee recommendations). For example, in a preferred embodiment, a composition comprises from about 9.0 to about 10.0% w/w protein, more preferably about 9.5% w/w. This corresponds to approximately 1.8 g protein/100 kcal. An advantage provided by this protein concentration is that it is equivalent to the amount of protein generally present in human milk and corresponds to the lower limit described in theCodex Alimentarias(Food Code). In general, the PLDM can represent between about 70 to about 100% of the total protein in the composition. Thus, it can also represent 75%, 80%, 85%, 90% or 95% of the protein in the composition. Thus, the sweet modified whey protein of the invention can generally be administered to an infant or young child as a dose of 1.6-3.2 g protein/100 kcal, preferably 1.6-2.2 g protein. /100 kcal and even more preferably 1.8-2.1 g protein/100 kcal. Administration method: (i) Administration to infants: PLD can be administered directly orally to infants, alone (pure or diluted in water or breast milk, for example) as a food supplement (for example, as or in conjunction with a fortifying human milk supplement), or as any milk booster used during trophic feeding, or as a pharmaceutical or nutraceutical composition, or as an ingredient in infant milk formula. Said formula can be a "preterm formula" if the offspring is born before term or has a low birth weight, a "starter formula" or a "continuation formula". The formula can also be a hypoallergenic (HA) formula in which cow's milk proteins are hydrolyzed. An example of such a start formula is given in Example 2. PLD can be administered as a growth milk or in any milk drink. (ii) Administration to young children: PLD can also be administered orally to young children in the form of a pharmaceutical or nutraceutical composition, growth milk, dairy drinks, food supplements, dairy yogurts, desserts and puddings, cookies and cereal bars, cereals, and fruit-based drinks. (iii) Administration to pregnant or lactating mothers: PLD can also be administered to pregnant or lactating mothers orally, preferably in food, drink, food supplement or pharmaceutical composition. (iv) Administration to animals: The PLD can also be administered orally to animals alone, or in water or in the form of a food supplement, a pharmaceutical or nutraceutical composition, or milk or feed. Administration with other compounds: PLD can be administered alone (pure, or diluted in water or milk, including breast milk, for example) or in a mixture with other compounds (such as food supplements, nutritional supplements, medicines, vehicles, flavorings, digestible or indigestible ingredients). ). Vitamins and minerals are examples of typical food supplements. In a preferred embodiment, the PLD is administered in a composition, eg, in infant formula, together with other compounds that enhance the described beneficial effect in young mammals. For example, this can be a probiotic. Other probiotics can also be administered. Preferably, for this purpose, the probiotic can be selected from the group consisting ofBifidobacteria, Lactobacillas, Lactococcas, Enterococcas, Streptococcas, Klayveromyces, Saccharoymces, Candida,in particular selected from the group consisting ofBifidobacteriam longam, Bifidobacteriam lactis, Bifidobacteriam animalis, Bifidobacteriam breve , Bifidobacteriam infantis, Bifidobacteriam adolescentis, Lactobacillas acidophilas, Lactobacillas casei, Lactobacillas paracasei, Lactobacillas salivarías, Lactobacillas lactis, Lactobacillas rhamnosas, Lactobacillas johnsonii, Lactobacillas plantaram, Lactobacillas salivarías, Lactococcas lactis, Enterococcas faeciam, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Saccharomyces boalardiio mezclas de los mismos , preferably selected from the group consisting ofBifidobacteriam longamNCC3001 (ATCC BAA-999),Bifidobacteriam longamNCC2705 (CnCm 1-2618),Bifidobacteriam longamNCC490 (CNCM 1-2170),Bifidobacteriam lactisNCC2818 (CNCM 1-3446),Bif idobacteriam brevestrain A,Lactobacillas paracaseinCc2461 (CNCM 1-2116),Lactobacillas johnsoniiNCC533 (CNCM 1-1225),Lactobacillas rhamnosasGG (ATCC53103),Lactobacillas rhamnosasNCC4007 (CGMCC 1.3724),Enterococcas faeciam SF 68(NCC2768; NCIMB10415), and their mixtures. Other examples of synergistic compounds that can be included in the compositions of the invention, especially in infant formulas, are prebiotic compounds. A prebiotic is a non-digestible food ingredient that beneficially influences the recipient by selectively stimulating the growth and/or activity of one or more bacteria in the colon, thus improving its health. These ingredients are non-digestible in the sense that they are not broken down or absorbed in the stomach or small intestine and therefore pass intact to the colon, where they are selectively fermented by beneficial bacteria. Examples of prebiotics include certain oligosaccharides, such as fructooligosaccharides (FOS), cow's milk oligosaccharides (OSLV) and galactooligosaccharides (GOS). A combination of prebiotics can be used, such as 90% GOS with 10% short-chain fructooligosaccharides such as the solid product sold under the trademark Raftilose® or 10% inulin such as the product sold under the trademark Raftiline®. Other examples of prebiotics that can be used in the context of the present invention include the group of oligosaccharides obtained from milk or other sources, optionally containing sialic acid, fructose, fucose, galactose or mannose. The preferred prebiotics are sialooligasaccharides (SOS), fructooligosaccharides (FOS), galactooligosaccharides (GOS), isomaltooligosaccharides (IMO), xylooligosaccharides (XOS), arabinoxylooligosaccharides (AXOS), mannanoligosaccharides (MOS), soybean oligosaccharides, glycosylsucrose (GS), lactosucrose ( LS), sialyl-lactose (SL), fucosyl-lactose (FL), Lacto-N-Neotetraose (LNNT), lactulose (LA), palatinosaoligosaccharides (PAO), maltooligosaccharides, gums and/or hydrolysates thereof, pectins, starches and/or hydrolysates thereof. An infant formula according to the invention preferably further contains at least one prebiotic in an amount of 0.3 to 10% of the total dry weight of the composition. In particular, oligosaccharides from human milk can be included in the composition according to the invention, for example sialylated oligosaccharides, described in WO 2012/069416 published May 31, 2012. These latter oligosaccharides can act synergistically with PLD of the invention for promoting the healthy development of the mammalian enteric nervous system in the infant or young child. The daily dose of carbohydrates, and other components administered with the PLD must always comply with published safety guidelines and regulatory standards. This is particularly important with regard to administration to newborn infants, especially those born with low, very low, or extremely low birth weights. A composition, eg an infant formula, containing the PLD for administration according to one embodiment of the invention, may contain an additional protein source in an amount such that the total protein is not more than 4.0, 3, 0 or 2.0 g/100 kcal, preferably 1.8 to 2.0 g/100 kcal. It is preferred that greater than 50% by weight of the protein source is whey, including Sweet Whey Modified (SLDM) and/or Sweet Unmodified Whey. The type of additional protein source is not considered critical to the present invention as long as the minimum requirements for essential amino acid content are met and satisfactory growth is ensured. In one embodiment, the protein content ranges from 30% to 80% whey protein. Therefore, additional protein sources such as skim milk, casein or soy can be used. In one embodiment, the casein/whey ratio ranges from 70/30 to 20/80. The proteins can be intact or hydrolyzed or in a mixture of intact and hydrolyzed proteins. It may be desirable to provide partially hydrolyzed proteins (with a degree of hydrolysis between 2 and 20%), for example, for babies thought to be at risk of developing cow's milk allergy. If hydrolyzed proteins are required, the hydrolysis process can be performed as desired as known in the art. The composition may also comprise a carbohydrate source and/or a fat source. Baby formula may contain a source of lipids. The lipid source can be any lipid or fat that is suitable for use in infant formulas. Preferred fat sources include palm oil, high oleic sunflower oil, and high oleic safflower oil. Essential fatty acids, linoleic acid and α-linolenic acid may also be added. One or more long-chain essential fatty acids (LC-PUFA) may be included in the composition. Examples of LC-PUFA that can be added include docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and arachidonic acid (AA). The LC-PUFAs can be added at concentrations such that they constitute more than 0.01% of the fatty acids present in the composition. Oils containing high amounts of preformed arachidonic acid and docosahexaenoic acid, such as fish oils or microbial oils, may be added as small amounts. Palmitic acid may be added, preferably at the Sn-2 position. In total, the fat content is preferably such that it provides a percentage between 30 to 55% of the total energy of the formula. The fat source preferably has a ratio of n-6 to n-3 fatty acids of from about 5:1 to about 15:1; for example, from about 8:1 to about 10:1. An additional source of carbohydrates can be added to the nutritional composition. Preferably, it provides about 40% to about 80% of the energy of the nutritional composition. Any suitable carbohydrate may be used, for example, sucrose, lactose, glucose, fructose, corn syrup solids, maltodextrin, or a mixture thereof. If desired, additional dietary fibers may also be added. If added, they preferably comprise up to about 5% of the energy of the nutritional composition. The additional dietary fiber may be of any suitable source, including, for example, soybean, pea, oat, pectin, guar gum, acacia, oligosaccharides including FOS, GOS and those described above, or a mixture thereof. . Suitable vitamins and minerals may be included in the nutritional composition in an amount that meets the appropriate guidelines. Examples of minerals, vitamins and other nutrients optionally present in infant formula include vitamin A, vitamin B1, vitamin B2, vitamin B6, vitamin B 12, vitamin E, vitamin K, vitamin C, vitamin D, folic acid, inositol, niacin, biotin, pantothenic acid, choline, calcium, phosphorus, iodine, iron, magnesium, copper, zinc, manganese, chlorine, potassium, sodium, selenium, chromium, molybdenum, taurine, and L-carnitine. Normally, the minerals are added in the form of salt. The presence and amounts of specific minerals and other vitamins will vary depending on the child population for which they are intended. The infant formula may optionally contain other substances, such as fibers, lactoferrin, nucleotides, nucleosides, and the like, which may have a beneficial effect. One or more food grade emulsifiers may be included in the nutritional composition, if desired; for example, tartaric acid diacetyl esters of mono- and di-glycerides, lecithin and mono- or di-glycerides or a mixture thereof. Similarly, suitable salts and/or stabilizers may be included. Flavorings may be added to the composition. Administration period: The term of administration may vary. When positive effects are expected with a relatively short time of dosing (for example, daily dosing for one to two weeks for neonates), longer times are thought to provide a potentiated effect, or at least maintain the effect in older infants (for example, within three, five, eight, or 12 months) or in children (for example, within 2 or 4 or 6 years). For administration to animals, the corresponding deadlines apply. (iv) Administration to animals: Sweet modified whey protein or standard sweet whey protein is given directly to the baby. This is particularly the case if the mother does not breastfeed or after she stops breastfeeding. However, a breastfed infant can also receive modified sweet whey protein or standard sweet whey protein by direct administration. Preferably, the administration to the baby is by daily intake. For example, if the modified sweet whey protein or sweet whey protein is administered as an infant formula, the administration is with each feeding, that is, from approximately four to approximately six times a day for infants, the number of feedings being reduced with the age. For young children (over one year), the administration may be less, once or twice a day. For babies who are already taking their first steps and children up to six years of age, the administration is recommended for the consumption of milk for growth and development. Administration to the baby by direct administration may continue up to six months or even a year or more. Therefore, modified sweet whey protein or standard sweet whey protein can be administered during lactation, if it occurs, or after partial or total weaning. The administration can continue throughout the baby stage that already takes its first steps and even up to six years. It is known that the enteric nervous system continues to develop in children up to this later age [Wester, T. et al. (1999); Notable postnatal alterations in the myenteric plexus of normal human bowel, Gut, 44: 666-674]. Therefore, the present inventors speculate that administration of modified sweet whey protein or standard whey protein may continue to have a positive effect, generally up to six years. Effect of the administration of the standard PLDM or PLD: Modified sweet whey protein, or standard sweet whey protein, given to neonates promotes healthy development of the enteric nervous system. In a rat model experiment detailed in Example 1, the effect of administration of a modified sweet whey protein (PLDM28) or a commercially available sweet whey protein (Lacprodan Di9224) on neuronal development was evaluated. In this experiment, pups that had had maternal diet-induced intrauterine growth retardation (RP group) and pups that had not had IUGR (CTRL) were supplemented, starting 2 days after birth, with water (controls; particularly CTR-a and RP-a) or with one of the following milk fractions:  - Lacprodan DÍ9224: Whey protein isolate, sweet whey, marketed by Arla Foods Ingredients, The Netherlands. - PLDM28: Sweet whey modified using a Nestlé patented procedure (cGMP removal). - FC concentrate: Growth factor concentrate, which is a high protein isolate (97% protein) extracted directly from skimmed milk and marketed by Tatua (Tatuani, New Zealand). Contains high levels of IGF and TGF. These fractions were administered to pups as isonitrogenous supplements (12% protein), such that the biological effect can be attributed to the qualitative content of the serum fraction rather than the amount of protein. The volume of the supplements was gradually adapted to accommodate the growth of the rat pups (150 pl/100 g body weight). Therefore, supplementation provided 1 to 5 mg of protein per day and per pup. The groups were the following: 1) CTRL-a: CTRL pups born from CTRL mothers, which received water supplementation. 2) RP-a: RP pups born from RP mothers, which received water supplementation. 3) RP-Lacprodan Di9224: RP pups born from RP mothers, which received a supplementation of Lacprodan Di9224. 4) RP-PLDM28: RP pups born to RP mothers, which received a PLDM28 supplementation. 6) RP- FC concentrate: RP pups born from RP mothers, who received a supplementation of FC concentrate. Two weeks after birth, at the time of sacrifice, the neuronal development of the pups was assessed using two methods: (I) a jejunal targeted gene expression profiling strategy, and (ii) measuring theex vivojejunal contractile response to a electrical field stimulation (ECE). The latter method measures the contractile response induced by the enteric nervous system and therefore the maturation and functional degree of the enteric nervous system. Theex vivocontractile response of the jejunum to acetylcholine was also evaluated, this measures the contractile response of the intestinal muscle itself, which therefore reflects the maturation and functional degree of the intestinal muscle. This latter experiment was performed as a control, to allow the inventors to separate the factors, ie, nervous system and muscle, by controlling the measured contractile responses. Ex vivocontractile response of the jejunum to electric field stimulation (ECE): To assess neuronal maturation in the protein restriction model and after supplementation with the sweet whey isolates of the invention, the contractile response of the jejunum to ECE was measured, which measures the involvement/capacity of the neural network to stimulate muscle contractility. The possible implication of any effect on intestinal muscle maturation due to protein restriction, or after supplementation with sweet whey isolates, was assessed by measuring the jejunal contractile response to acetylcholine. The contractile response of the jejunum to ECE was reduced in the RP-a group compared to the CTRL-a group, at the frequency of 10 Hz (P=0.040) (Figure 1). The jejunal contractile response to acetylcholine was slightly, but not significantly (P=0.181) reduced in the RP-α group compared to the CTRL-α group (Figure 2). Taken together, this reflects impaired neuromuscular interaction, and in particular impaired neuronal maturation, in the jejunum of protein-restricted pups. Supplementation with sweet whey fractions (Lacprodan Di9224 and PLDM28) significantly increased (P=0.007 and 0.026 respectively) the jejunal contractile response at 10 Hz to a level statistically similar to controls (Figure 1). This indicates a promoting effect of sweet whey fractions on neuronal stimulatory capacity in the jejunum, reflecting a promotion of neuronal development and function in the neonatal period. In fact, jejunal muscle compartment maturation was not significantly modified after supplementation with the sweet whey fraction (P=0.199 and 0.828 for Lacprodan Di9224 and PLDM28, respectively) since jejunal contractile responsiveness to acetylcholine remained unchanged compared to that of the PR-α group (Figure 2). Taken together, these data indicate that standard and modified sweet whey protein (Lacprodan Di9224 and PLDM28, respectively in the experiment) enhance the neural network-mediated muscle contractile response to electric field stimulation, ECE, in the jejunum of offspring of the RP group. This indicates that sweet whey protein promotes postnatal development and functionality of the enteric nervous system. Such a stimulatory effect was not observed in response to acetylcholine stimulation, suggesting that there is no enhancement of the smooth muscle contractile response in response to acetylcholine, ie, no promotion of postnatal smooth muscle maturation. Therefore, these data clearly show a beneficial effect of sweet whey protein in promoting neuronal development and function during the postnatal period. Based on these data, sweet whey constitutes a new nutritional solution to prevent or treat disorders associated with an immature and/or altered enteric nervous system in young mammals up to the age of approximately six years, in particular, during the neonatal period (usually defined as the first 6 six months of life, for a human being). Expression of genes involved in intestinal neuronal development: In the rat model experiment of Example 1, the effect of protein restriction, as well as protein restriction followed by supplementation with milk fraction, on the expression of major genes involved in biological pathways of neuronal development was studied, in the jejunum, using a gene expression profiling strategy. The genes studied are listed in Table 2 and the data is presented in Table 3. Data for unexpressed or misexpressed genes are not indicated. Among the remaining 35 genes expressed at a detectable level, in 18 of them (Table 3), a significant interaction between treatment (protein restriction) and complementation (dairy fractions) was observed. Genes that were significantly differentially expressed were those primarily involved in the maturation or differentiation of neurons and glial cells or were markers of neuronal growth and plasticity. The present inventors have previously shown (Cettour and Faure, manuscript in preparation) that compensatory mechanisms occur in protein-restricted (RP) pups to help promote cell and neuronal development in the small intestine. The present data confirm these findings. Specifically, the gene expression of neurotrophic factors and their receptors, such as NGF (Nerve Growth Factor),Gfra1 (GDNF family receptor alpha 1), Graf2 (GDNF family receptor alpha 2), Ntg3 (Neutrophin 4), S100B (S100 calcium binding protein B), and synaptophysin, were significantly upregulated in the RP-a group, compared to the CTRL-a group. Possibly this reflects an imbalance and a "stress" situation in the animals, which nevertheless continues to be insufficient to promote neuronal maturation as indicated by our results after electric field stimulation (ECE). Lacprodan Di9224 supplementation significantly increased gene expression of NGF, NGFr (Nerve Growth Factor Receptor) and Chrm3 (muscarinic receptor 3) and decreased that of S100B to an expression level similar to that of CTRL-α (Table 3). The increased gene expression ofNGFrandnGf, together with the increased expression of NGF in the RP group, suggests the promotion of neuronal growth, development, and survival observed in Figure 1 [Tessarollo, (1998) Pleiotropic functions of neurotrophins in development . Cytokine Growth Factor Rev. 9(2): 125-37]. It was observed that the levels of NGF and NGFr were increased in the RP-a group compared to those in the CTRL-a group, but that this increase was only significant for NGF. PLDM28 supplementation significantly increased gene expression of Crhr1, ApoE, NGFr, Ntf3 (neurotrophin 3), Chrm2 and 3 (muscarinic receptors 2 and 3), and TGFb2, and significantly decreased that of S100b. Again, increased gene expression of NGFr and Ntf3 may contribute to promoting neuronal growth and development and may, at least in part, explain the neuronal maturation observed in Figure 1. Muscarinic receptors such as those encoded by theChrm2andChrm3genes are involved in the contractility and motility of the intestinal musculature in response to Acetylcholine [Chen J, Wen J, Cai W. (2012) Smooth muscle adaptation and recovery of contractility after massive small bowel resection in rats. Exp Biol Med (Maywood). May 1; 237(5): 578-84]. Similarly, the corticotropin-releasing hormone (Crhr) receptor, also known as corticotropin-releasing factor, and apolipoprotein E, are involved in muscle contraction and motility pathways [Taché Y, Kiank C, Stengel A. (2009) A role for corticotropin releasing factor in functional gastrointestinal disorders Curr Gastroenterol Rep. Aug 11; (4):270-7;. Vincelette J, Martin-McNulty B, Vergona R, Sullivan ME, Wang YX, (2006) Reduced cardiac functional reserve in apolipoprotein E knockout mice Transl Res. Julio; 148(1):30-6.)]. After PLDM28 complementation, the expression of chrm3 and that of the aforementioned genes involved in muscle contractility pathways was significantly increased compared to that of RP-α. This might suggest promotion of intestinal muscle maturation, but this would warrant further attention as these increased gene expressions have not yet translated into measurable functional benefit as indicated by the unchanged contractility response to acetylcholine at pup sacrifice ( Figure 2). Supplementation with growth factor concentrate significantly increased Crhrl gene expression and significantly decreased that of GDFN, GFra1, Neurod1, S100b, and synaptophysin. Unlike PLDM28 and Lacprodan Di9224, there were no increased expression levels in the NGF pathway (nerve growth factor pathway) observed after supplementation with growth factor concentrate. This is consistent with the result that no beneficial effect on the neural network (ECE)-mediated contractile response of the jejunum (Figure 1) was observed after GF1 supplementation. The level of NGFr gene expression was significantly upregulated after complementation with either PLDM28 or Lacprodan Di9224, while the restriction protein-induced increased gene expression was maintained in these complemented groups. This clearly indicates stimulation of the NGF pathway. Neurotrophins, such as NGF, and their receptors, are expressed at a very high level in the peripheral and central nervous systems. Mouse gene targeting strategies have documented the role of neurotrophins in promoting developmental maturation of peripheral and central nervous system neurons, confirming their critical role in neuronal development. Reviewed in Tessarollo, L. (1998). NGF is also critical for the survival and maintenance of sympathetic and sensory neurons. Without it, these neurons undergo apoptosis [Freeman RS et al., (2004) NGF deprivation-induced gene expression: after ten years, where do we stand? "NGF and Related Molecules in Health and Disease". Prog. Brain Res. Progress in Brain Research 146: 111-26]. Nerve growth factor causes axonal growth. This shows that NGF circulates throughout the body and that it is important to maintain homeostasis [Levi-Montalcini R (2004). “The nerve growth factor and the neuroscience chess board”. Prog. Brain Res. 146: 525-7.] Human and bovine milk also contain NGF activity suggested to play a role in the postnatal neurodevelopment and neuroprotection of the newborn [Gaull, G.E., Wright, C.E. & Isaacs, C.E. (1985). Significance of growth modulators in human milk. Pediatrics. 75:142-145]. The gene expression modifications observed in Table 3, and in particular the stimulation of the NGF pathway, likely contribute to the observed promotion of neuronal stimulatory responses to ECE in the PLDM28 and Lacprodan supplemented groups shown in Table 3. Figure 1. The populations that can benefit from the invention are: - Preterm, low (<2500 g), very low (>1500 g) and extremely low (<1000 g) birth weight babies; - Premature or full-term babies who have had intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) that occurred after any adverse event during pregnancy; - Any neonate and infant showing delayed growth of the nervous system after, for example, hypoxaemia-ischaemia at birth or any other adverse event; - Any neonate and infant or child up to six years of age with gastrointestinal dysfunctions (digestive disorders, motility disorders, gastrointestinal reflux, slow gastrointestinal transit or oral food intolerance), Hirschsprung's disease and inflammation affecting the gastrointestinal tract (such as enterocolitis necrotizing) and pathologies related to obstruction. The invention is further described with reference to the following examples. It should be appreciated that the invention, as claimed, is not intended to be limited in any way to these examples. Example 1: Animal study (feeding and slaughter): Experiments on animals were carried out with authorization no. 2120 guaranteed by the Office Vétérinaire Cantonal, Etat de Vaud. Two-month-old female Sprague-Dawley rats were obtained after one week of gestation in Harlan, Barcelona. On the day of arrival, the mother rats were housed in individual cages and randomly assigned to control (CTRL) or protein restriction (RP) groups. Animals had access to food and water ad libitum and were maintained on a 12-h light/dark cycle. Table 1 details the diets of the mothers of the CTRL and RP groups. The CTRL group mothers received a control diet containing 20 % protein (casein) adapted to the protein needs of standard rats during gestation (Reeves, P.G., Nielsen, F.H., Fahey, G.C., JR. 1993. AIN-93 Purified Diets for Laboratory Rodents: Final Report of the American Institute of Nutrition Ad Hoc Writing Committee on the Reformulation of the AIN-76A Rodent Diet. J. Nutr. 123: 1939-1951.). Mothers in the RT group received a RP diet containing 10% protein (casein). Both diets were isocaloric, balancing the protein deficit with the addition of corn starch. Table 1: Composition of control diet (CTRL) and protein restriction (RP) AIN-93G Subsistence allowance CTRL RP Components Corn starch 53 63 Casein (K Caseinate) 20 10 Sucrose 10 10 Soybean oil 7 7 Cellulose 5 5 AIN-93G mineral mix 4 -AIN-93M mineral mix - 4 AIN-93 Vitamin Blend 1 1 Choline Bitartrate 0.25 0.25 L-Cysteine 0.3 0.3 Tert-butylhydroquinone 0.0014 0.0014 The mothers of the CTRL and RP groups received their respective diets during pregnancy and lactation until the day of sacrifice (14 days after growth (14 DDN). Two NDD pups were randomly assigned to dams from the same experimental group and litter size was adjusted to 9 pups per dam with a minimum number of four to five males per litter. From 2 DNA to 14 DNA, a daily supplementation of water or one of the following milk fractions was manually/pipetted to the control or treated groups, respectively. The volume of the supplementations was gradually adapted to match the growth of the rat pups (150 pl/100 g body weight). The groups and diets were as follows: 1) CTRL-a: CTRL pups born from CTRL mothers, which received water supplementation. 2) RP-a: RP pups born from RP mothers, which received water supplementation. 3) RP-Lacprodan Di9224: RP pups born from RP mothers, which received a supplementation of Lacprodan Di9224. 4) RP-PLDM28: RP pups born to RP mothers, which received a PLDM28 supplementation. 5) RP - FC concentrate: RP pups born from RP mothers, which received a supplementation of FC concentrate. The milk fractions were: - Lacprodan Di9224: whey protein isolate, sweet whey, marketed by Arla Foods Ingredients, Denmark. - PLDM28: sweet whey modified using a Nestlé proprietary process (cGMP removal). - FC concentrate: Growth factor concentrate marketed by Tatua, New Zealand. Contains enriched levels of IGF (Insulin-like Growth Factor) and TGF (Transforming Growth Factor). Fourteen NDD, a maximum of 10 pups from the CTRL and RP groups, were weighed and then euthanized by decapitation after anesthetizing with halothane. The peritoneal cavity was opened by longitudinal incision of the abdominal wall and the entire digestive tract was removed and the mesentery was removed. The first third of the jejunal segment after Treitz ligation was isolated and divided into several segments. One segment was washed abundantly with PBS at room temperature and placed in cold Krebs solution forex vivo contractile response measurements.One segment was rinsed with ice-cold PBS to remove luminal material, transferred to individual cryotubes, snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen, and held at -80°C until gene analysis. Neuronal development in the jejunum was assessed using two methods: (i) a targeted gene expression profiling approach and (ii) measuring theex vivojejunal contractile response to electric field stimulation (ECE). Ex vivocontractile response of the jejunum to electric field stimulation (ECE): Distal jejunum segments of approximately 1 cm in length, were placed in cold Krebs solution (CaCl2 (5 mM), MgCl2.6H2O (1.2 mM), NaCl (120 mM), NaH2PO4.H2O (1.2 mM) , NaHCOa (15.5 mM), KCl (5.9 mM), phenol red (0.005 mM), and glucose (11.5 mM)) pre-oxygenated with 95% O2/5% CO2. Intestinal segments were suspended along their longitudinal axis in a tissue bath (50 mL volume) loaded with 95% O2/5% CO2 oxygenated Krebs solution at 37°C. One end of the muscle was connected to a stationary clamp. The other end was connected by a rigid wire to an isometric force transducer. A stabilization period of 30 min was allowed to obtain spontaneous contractions. The tissue was then stretched to an initial length such that any further stretching would increase the tension at rest. Isometric contractility in the distal jejunum was induced with acetylcholine (10-5 M Ab) or with electric field stimulation (ECE, 5-10 Hz). The AC. was applied for 1 min. After completion of the dose response curve, the strips were tested with 80 mM KCl to ensure that their ability to contract was preserved. Signals were digitally recorded on a computer using Powerlab Chart 3.4. Results were normalized by cross-sectional area after carefully drying and weighing tissue fragments. Nonlinear fits were performed using Prism 4.0 (GraphPad Software, Inc., San Diego, USA). To obtain the frequencies, an analysis of the power density spectra of the measured signal was performed. A high pass filter was applied, with a cutoff frequency of 2 Hz (much smaller than the Nyquist frequency of 100 Hz). Welch's method was used to calculate the power spectrum density with 1.3 seconds of overlap imposing a low-frequency discretization: a series of frequencies was defined between 0 and 2 Hz, equally separated by 0.05 Hz. The calculations of the power spectrum density were performed using the Goertzel algorithm. Three frequencies corresponding to the three highest power values below 2 Hz were chosen. Gene expression profile: Using the phenol/chloroform method with TriPure® reagent (Roche Diagnostics, Basel, Switzerland), according to the manufacturer's instructions, total RNA was extracted from the jejunum of RP and CTRL pups. Briefly, frozen tissue samples (50-100 mg) were homogenized in 1 ml of TriPure® using the TissueLyser (Qiagen AG, Basel, Switzerland). Using the RiboGreen RNA Quantification Kit (Invitrogen-Molecular Probes, Carlsbad, CA) and RNA 6000 Nano LabChip Kit (Agilent Technologies) according to the instructions provided in the kits, the quantity and quality of isolated RNA was measured. Using an oligo (dT15) primer (Promega, Madison, WI) and the ImProm-N™ Reverse Transcription System (Promega) according to the instructions provided by the manufacturer, reverse transcription was performed with 1 µg of total Rn. T l 2: Li n n liz .  continuation  Expression levels of major genes involved in the development of the enteric nervous system (see Table 2) were assessed by quantitative, real-time, 2-step RT-PCR using the Sybergreen Profiler RT PCR microarray system (SABiosciences ). Measurements were performed in duplicate using specific sets of fluorescent TAMRA probes and primers during the log-linear phase of a PCR reaction with the Fas TaqMan 7600HT Real-Time PCR System (Applied Biosystems) using Sequence Detection Software version 2.2. . PCR reactions were performed in 2 μl wells pre-loaded with the manufacturer's specific primers and probes in each of the 384 wells of the reaction plate. The reaction was performed using a final cDNA sample concentration of 0.8 ng/µL with TaqMan Universal PCR Master Mix (Applied Biosystems) containing AmpliTaq Gold DNA Polymerase enzymes (Applied Biosystems), nucleotides, and fluorescent dye. ROX used as a passive load reference. The sequences of the primers and probes used were designed and validated at Applied Biosystems and taken from the rat on-demand assay library. The relative expression level of each gene was normalized by means of the geometric mean of control genes (those whose expression was statistically stable in all experimental groups under our conditions).
